p: In 1955, an outbreak of respiratory illness characterized by coughing, sneezing, and mucopurulent discharge was described in a colony of 20 chimpanzees at the Walter Reed Army Institute of Research (WRAIR) (Washington, DC, USA). During that episode, the RSV was isolated for the first time from a swab from the throat of a female chimpanzee and then called the chimpanzee coryza agent ( CCA) [ 82]. Viral isolation was performed in liver cells, later being inoculated in various laboratory animals, mice, hamsters, rabbits, rats, and chimpanzees, the latter being the only ones to develop specific symptoms.
